title: Cannot open firefox in private mode
content:
firefox: 108.0.1 (64-bit) windows 10: 21H2 installed browser: firefox (pin-ed private mode on task bar) and edge (set to always open in private mode)

When I open firefox by clicking the icon on the task bar, firefox is opened in private mode. When I type in a URL in the address bar and click return, the private mode icon disappears from the tab, and the firefox instance becomes a normal (non-private mode) window.

When I open firefox in regular mode, and click New private window menu button, a new firefox instance is open with no private-mode icon shown anywhere in the new window.

How can you tell if firefox is in private-mode or not? Does the new version of firefox really have private mode?

See the attached images: start firefox in private mode using the pin-ed icon on the task bar; then type in www.google.com in the address bar. After that, cannot tell if firefox is still in private mode.

By the way, I've cleaned all browser data, all, everything I can select in the settings. Still in private mode, I still get site suggestion from history. From privacy's point of view, something is wrong somewhere.
creator: hsheng

title: I am having problems using gmail plus even one additional tab
content: When I set up my computer, I have been using chrome for my work email and systems, and firefox for my personal email, for years now. This year I have found repeatedly that firefox will claim to have lost internet connection (ON A HARDWIRED COMPUTER) repeatedly during the day. And sometimes I will open a new tab to do a google search--and get a blank tab. Chrome works like a charm. No problems, ever. I have had IT work on this problem with me 5 times this fall (I'm in biological science). We have updated all the software and drivers, checked the computer's memory, checked the computer's upload and download speed, updated the docking station and replaced the wires. And Chrome works fine all the while. I think you have a problem, folks. I might have to ditch you.

title: Firefox Sync: Why aren't Shortcuts able to sync?
content:
Hello all,

There are a number of threads on this topic asking how to sync Shortcuts from one device to another. It appears that across the board the answer is that you cannot do this (see: this, this, this, this, or this to identify just a few).

It does appear to be the case that you can copy `browser.newtabpage.pinned` from `about:config` but this cannot be transferred to iPadOS, iOS, or easily shared between Android and macOS. It also does not update long term.

There have also been requests for this feature to be added (see this) though a lot of content around this topic appears to be confused as to what to call it and is notated within other recommendations.

I am wondering if anyone from the Mozilla/Firefox team can speak as to why this setting is not available, and what would be needed to see it become possible to sync shortcuts (and ```especially``` pinned shortcuts) within Firefox Sync.

Thank you!

title: Issue with large file upload using readAsDataURL and FileReader object when uploading a file with 700MB+ size.
content:
We are experiencing an error when trying to upload a large file using an HTML input uploader in Firefox. The file upload process is working properly in Chrome, but we are encountering issues when using Firefox. We have included a sample for reference and request assistance in resolving this problem. Please let us know if you have any suggestions for a solution.

sample : <input type="file" id="upload"> <button id="button">flie upload</button> <script> document.getElementById('button').addEventListener("click", function() { //debugger; var file = document.getElementById('upload').files; check(file[0]); }) function check(file) { return new Promise(function (resolve, reject) { var fileReader = new FileReader(); fileReader.readAsDataURL(file); fileReader.onload = function () { return resolve(fileReader.result); }; fileReader.onerror = function (error) { return reject(error); }; }); } </script>

title: Very slow compared to 3 other browsers and organization control
content:
Firefox takes 3 times, or more, to load web pages. It doesn't matter what else may be using parts of communication nor how badly Viasat (ViaSnail is my opinion) is throttling me. When they have me down to pre-56K dialup speeds Firefox frequently stalls. I am differentiating between browser stalls and website timeouts. I use Chrome mostly and Edge occasionally. Dell Inspiron 3670, I5 speedstep, 12GB RAM, NVME(?) 190GB system disk 90% empty, 2 SSD disks neither over 20% full, 1 950GB Sata disk partitioned in half. One I use for data the other is kept empty for emergency or backing up my other computer(s) data when I hose it testing my things or momentary lapse of reasoning.

Secondary concern is a message in settings telling me my organization is controlling the browser. I have no organization and do not recall granting permission to any biz or person. This may be due to Viasat ISP and you can be assured if there were ANY other option I'd use it. Cellular requires a bounce to get any signal into the valley my home is located. Very frustrating as it is a only 12 air miles to downtown San Jose, CA. Anywho that option takes 3 to 5 thousand in specialized equipment, solar power, 2 ubiquity dishes... among other unthought of pieces. It is also very close to the edge of legality under FCC rules. We did have it setup and worked fine on inbound side. Outbound side hitch hiked on ATT primary backhaul link from Fremont Peak to LA. It required an ATT cell phone plan to work constantly which is understandable.

My Dell runs fine and has no trouble with multiple browsers running alongside open chat, online games or other net intensive apps. As mentioned earlier I have run comparisons at various times of day/night and Firefox is always running less than 1/2 the speed of the others. I have gone through the settings and only made changes after reading docs to make sure what effect it would bring in. My work for 25 years was IT group and user tech support. Positions held run the gamut from Computer Ops, help desk at all levels, designing and building out technical help desks, then staffing positions, acquisition of work space and equipment, training as needed and managing the new department(s). So I do have well beyond a rudimentary understanding of computers from the IBM 3090 series down to PC with my first home computer bought in 1988. An aside here, text messaging we did every morning between Atari HQ in Sunnyvale, Ca communicating with Tokyo and Paris to verify financials, inventory for hardware manufacturing, order entry, sales... One cardinal rule was, NEVER use quit when done. I got sloppy one morning and did so. I did not realize all the groans about dam* computer is down were my fault on the way out to my car. Until getting home and finding 5 messages with increasing panic from the Computer Ops VP. I'm babbling, sorry.

To recap: 1) Firefox is extremely slow. 

              2) How to take back control of my browser on my machine

title: HTML displays as text only from the web
content:
I have a dozen old embedded device modules (circa 2003) which can host a web page. When I access the device through my local intranet (192.168.0.xxx), the web page displays correctly. However, when the same page is accessed through my DNS service (xxx.gotdns.org:xxxx) over the web, the Firefox INSPECT:network tool indicates that the document is type:text and displays the HTML in a text format. The first line of the HTML document is :<!DOCTYPE html>.....

These devices are non-secure information-only devices, but at least Firefox allows for HTTP: exceptions.

However, I cannot understand why Firefox treats the same content differently depending on the path. Is there a way to force Firefox to actually look at the contents of the packet and treat it accordingly?

creator: RogerN04

title: Should LastPass still be recommended, or even listed?
content:
Lastpass has had major data breaches in 2011, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2019, and two in 2022.

Today I got a recommendation to install LastPass. I was a bit surprised. LP (logmein, gotomypc) has a history of databreaches. I found reports in 2011, 2015, 2016, 2017, 2019, 2021, and two in 2022.

People without a lock on the door know they have no security. Putting on a lock that is not effective only gives people a false sense of security and may even increase the threat.

I love many of the add-ons. I know I can't rely on anyone to make sure they are all secure, but I hope such well-publicized problems will result in a review.

The billions lost and hundreds of hours spent by people each year with passwords in our fight with hackers is a true drain and a danger. Password programs have been the only way for individuals to survive. Their standards for security must be even higher than others. LastPass has not met the standard for a high level of security...or even a low level.]

LastPass has one reason for existing--keeping our passwords safe and secure. In the light of their failure, it's time to stop recommending them. It undermines the credibility of Mozilla and Firefox.

title: trouble with web speech after upgrade
content:
I run OctoPrint on a Raspberry Pi connected to a 3d printer that runs this speech plugin - https://github.com/jneilliii/OctoPrint-M117SpeechSynthesis

Previously, I was running Firefox under Ubuntu 18.04, but I had to upgrade to 22.04 for reasons. When I did Firefox updated itself as well, using a version (108) grabbed from the snap servers instead of the one from the repositories. When it did, this plugin was broken.

When I log into the OctoPi server through the Firefox browser, this plugin is supposed to show voices installed from which I can choose. That drop-down is empty now, though, so the plugin cannot speak.

Someone on reddit suggested I try using a .deb instead of the snap package. I couldn't find a .deb but I did try installing using the PPA as well as the direct download from mozilla.

Using the PPA instead of the snap, the web page for OctoPi hung without fully loading, with CPU usage for something called Isolated Web Co up to 50%!

Using the direct download and manual install method, that same process rose up to about 30 or 40% and the page took a minute before it finally fully loaded, but it did load and the plugin did find voices, so...

The issue does seem to be in the snap distributed version. I just can't deal with the load times and CPU usage of the other methods. But this does narrow it down, though...


Does anyone have any ideas on how I can fix this? I don't know what to look for and the plugin developer doesn't know, either.

title: scripting and redirecting by web sites
content:
'Why isn't there a way to stop scripting/redirecting when you click on a link? For example you click on a link thinking you are going to download something, but you are redirected to an AD site, or a Game site. Someone is racking up "clicks" for cash.

I.E. had a way to stop scripting altogether, or to allow you to choose to be be "asked" if you want to be redirected to another page, when a site wants to be redirected years age. So it shouldn't be that hard for you guys to set it up too.

I'm sure you just didn't think of it, but it is becoming a common problem with many sites, where someone manages to hack in a redirect an make some money getting "clicks", and worse, tricking people into downloading bogus shit programs like chromius.
